reviewText: I can't tell you what the movie is about because the audio is very bad.  I turned the volume up all the way and it still wouldn't be understandable.  :(  I love Myrna Loy in movies and was looking forward to seeing her in her first starring role. The visual quality was lacking, but it was watchable if only I could hear actual dialog.
The dialogue and the direction does not present the book and the author in a way that justifies this screenplay.

Do not buy! THIS VERSION IS A DVD-R MADE TO ORDER. I don't know why Amazon sells this when "Indecent" is just another working title for the very same 1932 Pre-code film "Vanity Fair" starring Myrna Loy. This film is still in print and available on dvd for $7.98. Vanity Fair (1932) The film is directed by Chester M. Franklin based on the novel by William Makepeace Thackeray. This is one of the Pre-code's that is an absolute joy to watch full of wicked amoral behavior & plunging necklines. Loy's Becky is much nastier than Miriam Hopkins' version 3 years later in Becky Sharp. Easily you can imagine Jean Harlow or Clara Bow in this role, not the future MGM's Miss Goody Two Shoes; which is who Myrna Loy became. Yes, before Myrna Loy became MGM's Miss Perfect Sweetness America - she was actually an actress!!; which makes her "Vanity Fair" & "Emma" MUST-SEES! VANITY FAIR was Loy's follow-up film to EMMA, in which she played a bratty and greedy daughter who almost destroys the loyal housekeeper (played by Marie Dressler). What makes Loy's fallen character so tragic is that she's supposed to be "genteel". Loy is the focus of all scenes & she has many outstanding/memorable scenes, such as the gambling scene in the casino where she tries to steal another woman's winning roulette bet! The more Loy's Becky loses her morality, the more beautiful she gets until she is finally "caught." Watch out for a rather shocking ending. Myrna Loy is absolutely stunning and gives a very solid performance. If you are at all a Myrna Loy fan; you can't miss out on : Vanity Fair (1932)!

The draw to this film was that it was Myrna Loy's first starring role. Loy's acting presaged that of a class actor. The supporting cast was sufficient. Film quality left something to be desired, close caption saved the day. The movie was after Thackery's Vanity Fair novel, and to be fair I have not read it. Many times novels don't transfer well to film. The story is set in England, perhaps early 1920s. It concerns a young woman (Loy) who enters into the child care aristocratic world really as a pretense for finding a sugar daddy. As the movie progresses she moves up the societal ladder. As she says in the film, "men want one thing from me...sex, and I want one thing from them...money." As years go by she gradually runs into hard times and as the movie ends she is older and penniless staring into a vanity mirror. Probably the best outcome for her. This was a precode film. It served a good lesson for adults about the possible ravages of promiscuity. Ironically, had this been a code film it likely would have been unequivocally morally correct; she probably would have ended up in prison, a suicide,or murdered. One wonders what the better message is.
I like Myrna Loy. I think that she was a great actress.

If you like the actress Myrna Loy, this is her first starring role and shows her star quality that made her great.  The story line is shallow and the recording quality by today's standards extremely poor.  But her performance is really the reason to see this movie.
I couldn't even finish watching it. The sound and film quality was very poor.
Great movie
Too old.  I like Myrna Loy, but the movie appeared to have silent movie actors in it that maybe shouldn't have transitioned to sound.
While I enjoyed stepping back in time and seeing the sights of a bygone era, the movie's story and its cautionary tale on manipulative women was slightly flat.

I loved seeing this movie and miss Loy did a great job in her acting. Of course times were different in those days. And technology was so very different back then. This move shows how people or folk are into getting rich and will do anything to achieve it. Even to loose the best thing they ever had. And in the end even to hitting rock bottom and losing friends by using deceit. If miss Loy we're alive today she would have been considered a Conservative. Even though she was a liberal and she says so in one of her interviews. She would be shocked at how liberalism has changed. There was some tech issues but if resolved. It would be worth seeing it again I saw a short piece of it on youtube and I must say it was much better. And I must say I love all her movies. This is the first time I saw it I hope maybe some day there will be a remake of this movie. I would buy this movie if the issues we're fixed. Just to have it in my movie collection anyway thanks for sharing. This movie had some good morals like character and integrity and loyalty and value if one looks for them. Which are lacking so much today.
This is a movie from the 30's and it is precode.  Myrna Loy is great as usual and the movie is filmed in black and white.

Evidently MGM lent Myrna Loy out to one of the Poverty Row studios for this adaptation of "Vanity Fair". The production values are not great - quite a contrast to the extravagant Technicolor "Becky Sharp" of a few years later. Loy is fun to watch and the movie is definitely pre-code enjoyable. (As one of the other reviewers notes, early in her career Loy was no goody-goody. Check her out as Fu-Manchu's daughter in "Mask of Fu-Manchu". Or as a Hindu in "Thirteen Women".) None of the film or TV adaptations of "Vanity Fair" that I have seen really does justice to the novel. However, this film is effective and worth a look. The streaming print is mostly watchable with some infrequent sound problems.

The audio quality was pretty poor, but I was so swept up in the story I didn't notice most of the time. I'd tried watching and reading Vanity Fair in other versions, but just never got into it, so I'm glad I found this quick-paced version. Myrna Loy was great and so were the wardrobes. I'm reviewing the Amazon Video version.
Outstanding Pre-code@@
Very sophisticated storyline considering the age and era of the film.  Surprisingly well done.  Myrna Loy does a fine job.

Vanity Fair or Indecent (1932)
Starring: Myrna Loy, Conway Tearle
This cinematic adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray's novel.
Stars Myrna Loy in her first starring role.
After 3 minutes, I decided that I could not bear the awful audio and video in spite of the film.
Myrna Loy shines!
A wonderful movie about a scheming woman who used people to her own regret.
A slightly dated but well done adaptation of Thackeray's Vanity Fair. Myrna Loy does a flawless Becky Sharp, but the adaptation is a bit old fashioned.
Love this old classic. There are several versions of this classic story about Rebecca Sharp. I am sure this is the first and the original that the others were based on.

Reluctant at first to view this film, the fact that Myrna Loy was in this, her first major film convinced us.  We were not disappointed as her looks and manner seduced nearly every male encountered.  Many a life and relationship was ruined including her own life.  Worth watching.
